Project Objectives: (i) To improve sanitary and environmental conditions in three major urban areas of the coastal zone covering a population of about 0.7 million; (ii) to improve and extend water supply and wastewater collection and disposal services in selected areas; (iii) to reduce groundwater and surface water pollution; (iv) to restore the recreational use of bathing beaches; (v) to ensure satisfactory operation and maintenance of equipment installed or rehabilitated under the National Emergency Reconstruction Program (NERP); and (vi) to improve service delivery through sector restructuring.
 ii Project summary Project Description: The project consists of: (i) extension of water supply facilities in Kesrouan and Nabatiye sub-project areas and of wastewater collection and disposal systems in Kesrouan, Saida, Sour and Nabatiye sub-project areas; (ii) operation, maintenance and training services contract(s) nation-wide; (iii) operation and maintenance equipment for five regional water authorities, or successor regional water and sanitation companies, and for environmental monitoring; (iv) consultant services, technical assistance and management contracts for the establishment, development and operation of sector institutions; and (v) consultant services for project management, engineering, construction supervision, environmental monitoring, and performance auditing. Benefits: The project will reduce existing wastewater pollution and restore beaches for recreational use; improve environmental and health conditions; and help protect water resources and provide safe drinking water. It will assist in restructuring the sector by combining the services of water supply with wastewater collection and disposal into regional authorities, or successor companies. These authorities/companies, to be operated on a commercial basis, will ensure improved quality of services. The project will also ensure satisfactory operation and maintenance of equipment installed or rehabilitated under the ongoing NERP. Risks: The project faces two major risks in addition to potential political instability in the region. The establishment of regional companies, which depends on legislative action, could be delayed and thus affect needed improvements in operational performance. Political pressure regarding tariff adjustments could impede regional authorities/companies from becoming financially viable. However, taking into account that there is an urgent need to reduce pollution and provide basic water supply and sanitation services, and that the Government is fully committed to restructure the sector to ensure service quality and financial viability, the risks are considered acceptable. Furthermore, to reduce direct political influence on tariffs, institutional reforms supported by the project include the establishment of the FRC for tariff review and approval. Poverty Category: The project is not part of a core poverty program but will include areas where poverty is acute. It will have a beneficial impact on poor households, which are sometimes forced to purchase water from vendors at relatively high prices. Improved water quality and sanitation will have a positive impact on reduction of water-related diseases, which mostly affect the poor. Economic Rate of Return: Estimated for water supply components only. It is 15 percent for both Kesrouan and Nabatiye sub-project areas. Map No.: IBRD 27466R Project Identification No.: 5342

BACKGROUND 1.1 Lebanon, which had been a prosperous middle-income country in the mid 1970s, is only now beginning to recover from the devastation caused by 15 years of violent civil strife and military occupation. Extensive damage to physical assets occurred, both as a direct result of the war, as well as through the accumulated effects of disruption in capital investment and maintenance. 1.2 The impact of the civil war on social conditions was equally grave. The loss of human resources was considerable; apart from the tragic loss of life and the disabling of hundreds of thousands of people, about 200,000 professional and skilled Lebanese sought employment in other countries. While this resulted in major shortages of skilled workers in various sectors of the economy, unemployment nevertheless is estimated to amount to 35 percent of the resident labor force, and is believed to be particularly high among urban youth. Nearly one quarter of the population of 3.6 million was displaced to live in unhealthy shanty towns and in semi-destroyed and vacated buildings in conditions of severe overcrowding. Public and social services were either non-existent or of poor quality, with only about one-third of power capacity operating, water treatment was inadequate as well as wastewater collection and disposal systems and most schools and hospitals were damaged. 1.3 To redress this situation, the Government embarked upon a National Emergency Reconstruction Program (NERP), which envisaged investments amounting to US$2.1 billion. Nearly three-quarters of this program is in the infrastructure sectors. The Government accords these sectors a high priority in order to provide a clean and healthy environment for Lebanon's inhabitants and to attract business and tourism, which are essential to the country's economic growth. II. THE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR A. Sector Issues and Constraints 2.1 Despite the country's comparative richness in water resources in a region of great water scarcity, the water supply and sanitation sector is in disarray and unable to provide adequate services to the majority of the population. Approximately half of all water produced is unaccounted-for because of losses and billing deficiencies, while leaking or overflowing wastewater collection systems contaminate water sources and water distribution networks. The division of responsibilities between water supply and wastewater affects operational efficiency and prevents joint planning and prioritization of investments. There is a lack of financial resources at every level, resulting from inadequate cost recovery, and of clear and transparent regulatory arrangements. The service deficiencies result both from the years of turmoil and neglect of infrastructure operation and maintenance and from more fundamental structural problems in the sector. B. Institutional Structure 2.2 The current allocation of responsibilities for water supply and wastewater is fragmented. While the Ministry of Hydraulics and Electric Resources (MHER) has primary responsibility for water resources and potable water supply, the Ministry of Agriculture is involved in the construction of
 2 Coastal Pollution Control and Water Supply Project irrigation systems, and the Litani River Authority is responsible for the planning, implementation and operation of all water uses in the Litani River water basin. There are 20 regional water boards and 200 local water committees responsible for irrigation and/or water supply operation and maintenance. Recently, MHER started the consolidation of the water boards and local committees into larger entities. 2.3 Responsibility for wastewater lies, in principle, with the municipalities, assisted by their sponsoring ministry, the Ministry of Municipalities and Rural Affairs. In practice, the municipalities have retained responsibility only for operation and maintenance, while for investments they depend on several ministries. The construction of wastewater collection systems has been mainly handled by the Ministry of Housing and Cooperatives, but is now the responsibility of MHER. The Ministry of Environment (MOE) is responsible for regulating the environmental impacts of waste disposal and the Ministry of Public Health for setting and monitoring the quality of water supplies and the public health aspects of waste disposal practices. The Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR) is responsible for economic and physical planning for the Government and for the coordination of projects with donor financing. The Sector Implementation Units (SIUs) in the MHER and MOE, which were established under the ERRP, are staffed by consultants responsible for project management. The SIUs report to their respective ministries and coordinate with the CDR. The Government's plans for sector restructuring include the merging of responsibilities for water supply and wastewater and a consolidation of the number of operating units with the initial creation of regional water authorities, which subsequently would be converted into regional water and sanitation companies. C. Sector Investment Program 2.4 The sector investment program under the NERP envisages overall investments in the range of US$1.0 billion over the next ten years for rehabilitation and extension of water supply and wastewater collection and disposal facilities. The emphasis is on wastewater collection and disposal due to past neglect and the need to reach a satisfactory level of service to improve public health and attract business and tourism. The first three years of the program have been devoted mainly to rehabilitation of existing works, with funding provided by the Bank, the European Investment Bank (EIB), the Arab Fund, the Saudi Fund, the Kuwait Fund, Germany (KfW) and France. In Greater Beirut, KfW is funding the rehabilitation of the southern wastewater disposal works at Ghadir, while construction/rehabilitation of the northern wastewater disposal works at Dora is being considered for funding through private investments. Rehabilitation and extension of Tripoli's wastewater collection and disposal system is expected to be funded by the EIB. The project will cover the priority wastewater collection and disposal systems in the remaining major coastal population centers of Kesrouan, Saida and Sour. 2.5 Future projects are expected to be increasingly undertaken by the private sector, once the framework for sector reforms and private sector participation has been established. The Bisri dam and Awali Conveyor (for Greater Beirut water supply) are two major projects likely to attract the private sector, as are works required for improved wastewater treatment for coastal discharge. D. Rationale for Bank Involvement 2.6 The project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy, discussed by the Board on June 30, 1994, which focuses on the rehabilitation of infrastructure, including addressing environmental concerns, and the increasing role of the private sector in the provision of public services. The project assists the Government in the transition from emergency reconstruction to investment that supports increasing economic prosperity and the establishment of institutions to lead the sector into the next century. In March 1993, Bank activity resumed in Lebanon with the approval of a loan of US$175 million for the Emergency Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Project (ERRP), which financed high priority components of the NERP in the fields of power, water supply and wastewater, solid waste,
 Coastal Pollution Control and Water Supply Project 3 education and telecommunications. Implementation is proceeding well, after some initial delays. A Supplementary Loan of US$50 million to the ERRP, which also includes funding for repair of water supply, wastewater and power facilities damaged during the April 1996 hostilities, was approved by the Board on May 30, 1996. Bank involvement in this project will help implement the sector restructuring initiated under the ERRP and promote effective private sector participation. It will help ensure the attainment of the sector objectives, particularly cost recovery, and enhanced accountability. The Bank is in a unique position to assist because of its experience in the sector and its ability to attract support from other donors. III. THE PROJECT A. Development Program 3.1 Damage Assessment Reports prepared for the NERP have served as background documentation for the preparation of feasibility and engineering studies for rehabilitation and a first-phase extension of water supply and wastewater facilities throughout the country. In 1994, a previously prepared sanitation master plan was updated, which resulted in the Lebanon's Staged Wastewater Program. The program provides, on a national basis, an analysis of present sanitary conditions, future requirements and investment priorities. This, in conjunction with a Water Resources Development Program, scheduled for preparation during 1997, will set the stage for major investments to be made in the water supply and wastewater sector. Studies have shown that environmental conditions along the coast are in comparison more severe than for the inland areas, and priorities have been determined accordingly. B. Project Objectives 3.2 The objectives of the project are to: (i) improve sanitary and environmental conditions in three major urban areas of the coastal zone covering a population of about 0.7 million; (ii) extend water supply and wastewater services in selected areas; (iii) reduce groundwater and surface water pollution; (iv) reduce the pollution in the sea to restore beaches for recreational use; (v) ensure satisfactory operation and maintenance of equipment installed or rehabilitated under the NERP; and (vi) restructure the sector to achieve improved services through commercial operation and increased private sector participation. C. Project Description 3.3 The project consists of the following major components: (a) extension and rehabilitation of water supply facilities in the Kesrouan and Nabatiye sub- project areas and wastewater collection and disposal systems in the Kesrouan, Saida, Sour and Nabatiye sub-project areas; (b) operation, maintenance and training services contract(s), country-wide, for mechanical and electrical equipment installed or rehabilitated under the NERP, including procurement of consumables and spare parts; (c) operation and maintenance equipment and office facilities for the five regional water authorities or successor regional water and sanitation companies (paras. 5.2(d) and 5.3), and operational equipment for environmental monitoring; and For Sour and Saida the water supply services will be improved and extended concurrently with this project with financing, to an amount of US$35 million equivalent, provided by the Arab Fund.

The wastewater components include extension and rehabilitation of networks, interceptors and trunk mains, pumping stations and treatment works, and submarine outfall mains. Details of the water supply and wastewater components are described in Annex 1. 3.5 The design standard for proposed wastewater treatment works and outfall mains is based on the Mediterranean Action Plan (MAP) for the protection and development of the Mediterranean Basin.2 The objective adopted by the Mediterranean countries is the provision of secondary treatment in all coastal cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants and of preliminary or primary treatment in all towns with more than 10,000 inhabitants. Under the project it is proposed, with the exception of Sour, to provide in a first phase for preliminary treatment with the outfall mains to be designed to satisfy the adopted standard on faecal coliform pollution. In a subsequent phase, secondary treatment will be added, for which the timing will be subject to the results from proposed environmental monitoring. In Sour, it was proved to be feasible to initially provide for secondary treatment and also to use the treated effluents for irrigation. In each sub-project area, an analysis of alternatives was carried out and selected project components represent least cost solutions. Industrial effluents should be pre-treated where required, and satisfactory arrangements should be made for the servicing of septic tanks. During negotiations, assurances were given by the Gevemment that rules preventing the discharge into the public wastewater collection systems of industrial effluents containing toxic/harmful substances, as identified in the "Land Based Sources Protocol",3 will be enforced from January 1, 2000. 3.6 Operation, maintenance (O&M) and training services contract(s), covering the whole of Lebanon, with a duration of three years will be entered into for mechanical and electrical equipment installed or rehabilitated under the NERP. These contracts, which will also include training of existing and new O&M staff, would, at a later date, be incorporated under the management structure and work program of the five regional water authorities, or successor regional water and sanitation companies. D. Project Management and Monitoring 4.8 The project management and monitoring systems established for the ongoing ERRP will basically be maintained. The SIU, or its successor, will continue to perform the project management function, directly reporting to the MHER and coordinating with the CDR, which will act as overall coordinator and planner, including specific functions on procurement and disbursements such as entering into contracts and effecting payments. The contractor(s) for the provision of operation, maintenance and training services will report directly to the Director General for Operations of the MHER, who will appoint an auditor (a local firm) for review and supervision of the contractors' performance. The institutional specialist will manage the process of sector reforms and report to a Steering Committee chaired by the Minister of MHER. Areas close to wastewater outlets into the sea have shown bacteriological pollution, and the Ministry of Environment (MOE) has closed some beaches for bathing because of public health risks. According to a UNICEF estimate, based on a 1991 study, some 80 percent of public water supplies in Lebanon were polluted. The EAs predict that through the project there will be a general improvement in public health conditions, and that beaches for recreation along the coastal areas of Kesrouan, Saida and Sour will be restored. Furthermore, the provision of new and the rehabilitation of defunct wasterwater collection mains will eliminate or significantly reduce the risk for bacteriological pollution of groundwater and local springs. (b) Impacts related to design of facilities and equipment: The most critical project components are the wastewater treatment works and the sub-marine outfall mains. Criteria have been established for the design, which will be based on data to be gathered and analyzed during an oceanographic survey covering a one year period. A monitoring program for the coastal waters will be carried out, and land at the treatment sites has been reserved for a later extension to secondary treatment. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Coastal Pollution Control and Water Supply Project are (1) to improve sanitary and environmental conditions in three major urban areas of the coastal zone; (2) to improve and extend water supply and wastewater collection and disposal services in selected areas; (3) to reduce groundwater and surface water pollution; (4) to restore the recreational use of bathing beaches; (5) to ensure satisfactory operation and maintenance of equipment installed or rehabilitated under the National Emergency Reconstruction Program (NERP); and (6) to restructure the sector to improve services through commercial operation and increased private sector participation. The project consists of the following major components: (1) extending water supply facilities in Kesrouan and Nabatiye sub-project areas and wastewater collection and disposal systems in Kesrouan, Saida, Sour, and Nabatiye sub-project areas; (2) entering into countrywide operation, maintenance, and training services contracts for mechanical and electrical equipment installed or rehabilitated under the NERP, including consumable and spare part procurement; (3) obtaining operation and maintenance equipment and office facilities for the five regional water authorities and for environmental monitoring; and (4) securing consultant services and technical assistance to establish and develop sector institutions nationally and regionally, for environmental monitoring, for project management, for construction supervision and performance review auditing.
